An intern sent you an encrypted flag using RSA, but mistakenly used Blum integers for the modulus. Can you decrypt the message? Ciphertext: 4921626471015557640077866037635369342841829511829570231618729323254846230352936202396469194011842231746752434789293268426897700611046144309853112625299740

The flag format is flag{...}
n=7625282723347498529160198073367762399954892198264311952312298331306619876080108100226856551809363224688696674957501977196793917572960949417756155166353529, e=2423093927911717930167466318820634622646065218481113134868284640457418525663089998148934676277751787651923978945612793627610647517999498774106483410781339
The lower 104 bits of p are: 28293690509838743635839204355150452927


---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{fwzzdx89}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 4921626471015557640077866037635369342841829511829570231618729323254846230352936202396469194011842231746752434789293268426897700611046144309853112625299740
vulnerability: blum integers
hint: Blum integers are products of primes congruent to 3 modulo 4. These integers have unique properties in cryptography.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=7625282723347498529160198073367762399954892198264311952312298331306619876080108100226856551809363224688696674957501977196793917572960949417756155166353529, e=2423093927911717930167466318820634622646065218481113134868284640457418525663089998148934676277751787651923978945612793627610647517999498774106483410781339
The lower 104 bits of p are: 28293690509838743635839204355150452927

extra_info: p=106296997250840376680931462330381047231368547080807942477982002005580619716799, q=71735636194438348288437744151868813619167435758651874941877072264776740099271, Ï†(n)=7625282723347498529160198073367762399954892198264311952312298331306619876079930067593411273084393855482214425096651441213954457755541090343485797806537460
